body_html:
I only have a modest experience with tensorflow. So my opinion might change. But my past does include two decades of experience developing computer system software. My view is that the big problem with tensorflow is mainly that it is intrinsically hard. No group is able to architect a complex UI in advance of any experience with developing and using it. On a realistic scale, I would give tensorflow an high grade. But, it is certainly a work in progress that is hard to understand by those developing it, hard to understand how to use it, and even harder to use productively after it is understood. I think the base design did make a big mistake with a configuration architecture that left major objects like the session context and the default graph as implicit global variables. I also am skeptical of the value of eager mode. Had the base design been better, perhaps only one architecture would have emerged for models, graphs, and layers. But, I doubt that navigating the variations in the different object models that have been built on top of the tensorflow python base will prove to be the limiting factor for most people in working with tensorflow
…

body:
I only have a modest experience with tensorflow.  So my opinion might change.
But my past does include two decades of experience developing computer system
software.  My view is that the big problem with tensorflow is mainly that it is
intrinsically hard.  No group is able to architect a complex UI in advance of
any experience with developing and using it.  On a realistic scale, I would give
tensorflow an high grade.  But, it is certainly a work in progress that is hard to
understand by those developing it, hard to understand how to use it, and even harder to use
productively after it is understood.  I think the base design did make a big
mistake with a configuration architecture that left major objects like the
session context and the default graph as implicit global variables.  I also am skeptical of
the value of eager mode.  Had the base design been better, perhaps only
one architecture would have emerged for models, graphs, and layers.  But, I
doubt that navigating the variations in the different object models that have
been built on top of the tensorflow python base will prove to be the limiting
factor for most people in working with tensorflow
